article.description:
Kyle Korver had 24 points and 11 rebounds
Saturday and (No. 14 ESPN/USA Today, No. 13 AP) Creighton overcame a 13-point deficit to defeat Southern Illinois 85-76.
article.headline: Korver sets conference career mark for 3-pointers in win
article.linkText: Korver, Creighton forced to rally to beat Salukis
article.story: OMAHA, Neb. (AP) -- Just when Southern Illinois thought it had Creighton's Kyle Korver under wraps, the sharp-shooting senior forward quickly emerged. Korver, held to one 3-pointer and seven points in the first half, hit three 3-pointers in a 56-second span in the middle of the second half Saturday to send the (No. 14 ESPN/USA Today, No. 13 AP) Bluejays over Southern Illinois 85-76. "You hit a couple, and you want to hit a couple more,'' said Korver, who finished with 24 points and 11 rebounds. Korver's shots not only brought the Bluejays back from a 13-point deficit, they made him the Missouri Valley Conference's all-time leader in 3-pointers. He now has 317. Southern Illinois' Shane Hawkins had owned the record of 314 from 1995-99. Korver's fifth 3-pointer of the game, with 8:07 left, gave the Bluejays a 65-62 lead, and they never trailed again against a Saluki team that won two of their three meetings last season. "Last year we lost to them, and for a while I thought it was going to happen again,'' Korver said. "It didn't, thankfully.'' Korver's rapid-fire 3-pointers turned a 47-44 deficit into a 53-50 lead with 13:47 left in the game. "Once Korver starts hitting 3s,'' Southern Illinois forward Jermaine Dearman said, "they're pretty hard to beat.'' Southern Illinois coach Bruce Weber said that even though it's early in the conference season, Saturday might have been the Salukis' best shot at catching the Bluejays in the conference race. The Salukis (10-4, 5-1) and Bluejays (15-1, 6-0) meet again March 1 in Carbondale, Ill. "I'll be honest with you, they could go 18-0,'' Weber said. House finished with 14 points and Michael Lindeman 12 for the Bluejays. Dearman led the Salukis with 18 points, Darren Brooks had 17 points and 11 rebounds and Kent Williams and Josh Warren 12 points apiece. Creighton chipped away at its 45-37 halftime deficit, with Southern Illinois going scoreless on its first eight possessions of the second half. The Salukis shot just 42.4 percent after halftime. "We went too fast and shot too early in the shot clock and took some questionable shots,'' Weber said. "Even when we got inside we just didn't finish.'' The Salukis committed five of their eight second-half turnovers in the first six minutes after the break. "We started playing hard,'' Korver said. "That was it. The first half, they were beating us on the boards and beating us to loose balls. Coach was all over us at halftime, obviously, and that was it.'' The Bluejays got baskets from House and Brody Deren and three free throws by Korver to pull to 45-44 before Brooks' putback gave the Salukis a three-point lead. Korver then tied and broke the MVC 3-point record, all in a minute, to put the Bluejays in front. "We ran some stuff for Kyle, and Kyle hit some baskets,'' Creighton coach Dana Altman said. "We probably didn't do a good job of running plays for him in the first half, and that was as much my fault as anybody's.'' The Salukis scored 14 straight points in taking a 40-27 lead with 4:16 left in the first half. The Bluejays scored on four of their last five possessions of the half to pull within eight points at the break. The crowd of 10,474, which included former Nebraska football coach and Congressman Tom Osborne, was the fifth-largest in Civic Auditorium history.
